article title: Bugged Bins: Local cities tracking your trash
Text:
CHESAPEAKE -- Several cities in Hampton Roads are using advanced computer technology to track their residents' recycling habits.

The technology--radio frequency identification, or RFID for short--is a type of computer chip that uses radio waves to transmit information in real time.

In the case of recycling bins, cities are purchasing bins with RFID tags on them that communicate to a radio antenna each time the bin is dumped into the truck.



In Hampton Roads, the cities of Chesapeake, Norfolk and Suffolk use the technology. The city of Virginia Beach is slowly implementing an RFID program of its own by purchasing new bins outfitted with RFID chips to replace older bins.

At roughly $1.50 per chip, the cities who use RFID technology in their recycling bins say the chips provide a host of benefits at a relatively small cost.

"It does many things for us," said Chesapeake Waste Administrator David Thompson. "One of the biggest things, as far as the city is concerned, is we're able to keep up with the inventory of cans."

Beyond tracking city-owned cans, Thompson said RFID chips allow his staff to keep track of how many residents are participating in the city's voluntary recycling program. Thompson said the more residents who recycle, the less trash that is hauled to the dump.

"Last year, Chesapeake recycled about 16,700 tons of recycling material and the more we can get into [a recycling bin], the less that goes into [a dump] at $125 a ton," Thompson said.

But some residents--many of whom may not even known their recycling habits are being monitored--may feel uneasy about the city's ability to collect data at their doorstep.

Jeremy Gillula, a technologist for the non-profit Electronic Frontier Foundation, said putting RFID chips in recycling bins is a less-intrusive use of the technology than what other industries are doing.

"It sits, you know, either at the curb or you bring it in the garage or up the driveway. So, given that, there doesn't seem to be a whole lot of concern for the presence of the RFID tag," Gillula said.

Instead, the real concern, Gillula said, was in how cities are handling the data once it is collected.

"Is it going to be shared with other government agencies? Or with companies?" he asked. "That's always a question when you have data being collected."

Thompson said that although he has the ability to request data about individual households' recycling habits, he does not get that information. Instead, he said, he looks at data about individual neighborhoods and the entire city.

We do go in sometimes and look at certain neighborhoods where we're not seeing the number that we would like to see," Thompson explained. "But as far as looking at address by address, we don't do that. We don't want to be that intrusive."

Similarly, a spokesman for the city of Suffolk said the city does not request data about individual households, either, even though that data is collected and could be provided.

Lori Crouch, a city of Norfolk spokeswoman, said Norfolk tracks participation through quarterly reports it receives from TFC but does not regularly get household-specific data.

"RFID tags also track actual resident participation in the recycling program, providing data for efficient use of targeted outreach and advertising efforts," Crouch said. Nikolas Larum manages the hauling operation for TFC Recycling, the company contracted by most cities in Hampton Roads to collect recycling.

Larum said the RFID technology helps him and his staff track the progress of collection trucks as they work in the field and improves driver efficiency by allowing them to easily remember where their last pick-up was.

"For our purposes, it's great because we can see the progress of our truck and we can see if the cart has been serviced," Larum explained.

Larum pushed back on the suggestion that the data his company tracks through the RFID chips is invasive.

"We're collecting the primary habit or if the person put their cart out to the curb," he said.

David Thompson, the waste administrator in Chesapeake, echoed a similar sentiment.

"Our goal is to try and help the city pull more tonnage out of the waste stream and save money," Thompson said. "That's the goal. It's not to see who is doing what." Larum also pointed to a program operated in partnership with his company called Recycle Perks that allows customers to receive benefits tied to how frequently the recycle.
The program requires residents to provide detailed customer information and consent to having their recycling habits be tracked.

A spokeswoman for Recycle Perks, which is a sister company of TFC Recycling, said the program has been a hit with customers.

article title: Va. Beach middle schoolers experience hands-on technology
Text:
VIRGINIA BEACH-- Some Virginia Beach middle school students spent the day in hands-on science and technology classes.

Nearly 900 kids at Corporate Landing Middle School took part in STEM day. STEM stands for science, technology, engineering and math.

There were more than 50 demonstrations ranging from aeronautical engineering to robots used by SWAT teams.

'These are skills the kids need for the future. So that is creative thinking, critical thinking, problem solving so that's what it is all about,' said principal Daniel Smith.

Smith added the school is looking for more ways to include the STEM education into the curriculum.

article title: New digging method will expand Hampton Roads Bridge-Tunnel
Text:
NORFOLK, Va. (AP) - Some of the world's most sophisticated tunnel technology will be used to expand the Hampton Roads Bridge-Tunnel.

The Daily Press reported Thursday that contractors will use a massive machine to dig through the soil under Hampton Roads Harbor.

The digging will be a change from the previous method used to build or expand bridge-tunnels in coastal Virginia. That method involved submersing prefabricated pieces of tunnel into a trench. Contractors will add a new bridge-tunnel parallel to the existing ones that carry Interstate 64 from Norfolk to Hampton.

The project will accommodate more traffic and will cost $3 billion-plus. The state expects to choose a contractor for the project early next year.

article title: Work underway to keep cybersecurity talent from leaving Hampton Roads
Text:
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. (WVEC) -- Teenagers are being taught to hack... but not in order to commit a crime. It's so they know how to defend against cyber attacks. "We actually hack in order to defend the hack, but it’s all ethical hacking," said Linda Lavender, an instructor at Advance Technical Center in Virginia Beach.

But after learning those skills at Advance Techjnology Center, Hampton Roads lost Chris Hultin to a better paying job Texas.

"There’s not nearly as much in the private technology sector in Hampton Roads," said Hultin, a former student at ATC who honed his skills under Lavender.

Just like our service members on the front lines of combat, these teenagers are our new soldiers in the cyber-war, where there were an estimated 160 successful cyber-attacks per week in 2015! That was up from 50 per week in 2010, according to data collected by the Ponemon Institute.

"These are the attackers who are launching the attack as you can see going across," said current ATC student Cory Petko.

The 16-year-old showed us a map that shows real-time cyber attacks from China launched against the U.S.

But for the 475 students that graduate from ATC every year, getting a job here may not be so easy.

"Are the benefits and the pay here? Maybe, no," said Lavender.

Better incentives such as more money were offered to Hultin, who took a job in Austin.

According to a report that was released last week, Austin is one of the nation's 20 largest cities that saw their population grow last year, blustered in part by the cybersecurity industry.

"We’ve got over 200,000 un-filled cyber jobs. Virginia alone has 18,000 and these jobs pay an average salary of $88,000," said Sen. Mark Warner, who has been working to make Hampton Roads and the Commonwealth attractive to Cybersecurity companies.

Learning the skills for that type of job isn't only happening at ATC, but also Old Dominion University's cybersecurity program.

Norfolk State University got a visit from Vice President Joe Biden last year, after it won a $25 million grant for its cybersecurity program.

On the local level, Norfolk city leaders voted to offer tax incentives to lure tech companies last week. Chesapeake, Suffolk and Newport News have similar programs and so does Virginia Beach, which is home to the cybersecurity firm IntellecTechs. "Because we have the talent down here, we could certainly make a good story to have those jobs down there," said owner Jeri Prophet, who notes that a regional effort would be greatly beneficial to the Hampton Roads area.

That regional push recently started with help Rob Hegedus.

The CEO of Suffolk-based cyber risk management company Serra-Brynn is part of a newly formed group called "Cyber Protection Resources."

"From an advertisement perspective and from a lobbying perspective, they’re situated very well to be able to kind of demonstrate to the rest of the world that we have the talent here. And that we can absorb some of the additional work that’s coming up," said Hegedus, whose company was ranked as one of the top 10 cybersecurity companies in the country and 16th in the world.

While the regional effort ramps out, Virginia Beach city leaders are trying to lure what they call a major cyersecurity company to the city.

Negotiations are still ongoing, so the name of that company hasn't been released just yet.

We'll follow it, and let you know when a decision is made.

virginia beach  va  (wvec) -- teenagers are being taught to hack    but not in order to commit a crime  it's so they know how to defend against cyber attacks  "we actually hack in order to defend the hack  but it’s all ethical hacking " said linda lavender  an instructor at advance technical center in virginia beach 

but after learning those skills at advance techjnology center  hampton roads lost chris hultin to a better paying job texas 

"there’s not nearly as much in the private technology sector in hampton roads " said hultin  a former student at atc who honed his skills under lavender 

just like our service members on the front lines of combat  these teenagers are our new soldiers in the cyber-war  where there were an estimated 160 successful cyber-attacks per week in 2015! that was up from 50 per week in 2010  according to data collected by the ponemon institute 

"these are the attackers who are launching the attack as you can see going across " said current atc student cory petko 

the 16-year-old showed us a map that shows real-time cyber attacks from china launched against the u s 

but for the 475 students that graduate from atc every year  getting a job here may not be so easy 

"are the benefits and the pay here  maybe  no " said lavender 

better incentives such as more money were offered to hultin  who took a job in austin 

according to a report that was released last week  austin is one of the nation's 20 largest cities that saw their population grow last year  blustered in part by the cybersecurity industry 

"we’ve got over 200 000 un-filled cyber jobs  virginia alone has 18 000 and these jobs pay an average salary of $88 000 " said sen  mark warner  who has been working to make hampton roads and the commonwealth attractive to cybersecurity companies 

learning the skills for that type of job isn't only happening at atc  but also old dominion university's cybersecurity program 

norfolk state university got a visit from vice president joe biden last year  after it won a $25 million grant for its cybersecurity program 

on the local level  norfolk city leaders voted to offer tax incentives to lure tech companies last week  chesapeake  suffolk and newport news have similar programs and so does virginia beach  which is home to the cybersecurity firm intellectechs  "because we have the talent down here  we could certainly make a good story to have those jobs down there " said owner jeri prophet  who notes that a regional effort would be greatly beneficial to the hampton roads area 

that regional push recently started with help rob hegedus 

the ceo of suffolk-based cyber risk management company serra-brynn is part of a newly formed group called "cyber protection resources "

"from an advertisement perspective and from a lobbying perspective  they’re situated very well to be able to kind of demonstrate to the rest of the world that we have the talent here  and that we can absorb some of the additional work that’s coming up " said hegedus  whose company was ranked as one of the top 10 cybersecurity companies in the country and 16th in the world 

while the regional effort ramps out  virginia beach city leaders are trying to lure what they call a major cyersecurity company to the city 

negotiations are still ongoing  so the name of that company hasn't been released just yet 

we'll follow it  and let you know when a decision is made

article title: Tool gives caregivers insight into dementia
Text:
“She can't tell me when she's in pain,” Priscilla Saunders says about her mother who was diagnosed with dementia. “She can't tell me when she's thirsty. She can't tell me any of those things, so I have to be able to watch her just like an infant.” HAMPTON, Va. (WVEC) -- Technology, available right here in Hampton Roads, is now helping caregivers get insight into their loved ones' dementia, which often creates debilitating memory loss, confusion and personality changes.

Now, people caring for those suffering can truly understand what's going on. Here's the concept behind that Virtual Dementia Tour: Imagine the difference you could make if you fully understood the physical, emotional and cognitive changes dementia is causing in your loved one.

There are days Priscilla Saunders doesn't recognize the mother she is so close to.

“Her personality is nothing like it used to be,” she described.

Diagnosed with Alzheimer's and dementia in 2009, Thelma Hill's cognitive abilities have declined steadily. She's not alone; statistics show every 67 seconds someone in the United States develops Alzheimer's. For Priscilla, like many caregivers, the disease has created a role reversal of sorts.

“She can't tell me when she's in pain,” Priscilla explained. “She can't tell me when she's thirsty. She can't tell me any of those things, so I have to be able to watch her just like an infant.”

She hesitates to put into words just how difficult the loss is for her.

“To see the personal things that no longer mean anything to them just is devastating,” the loving daughter lamented.

Even though Priscilla and her brother visit their mother every single day, she didn't know, she really couldn't know, exactly what the almost-92-year-old is going through.

So when Commonwealth Assisted Living and Memory Care in Hampton, where Thelma lives, offered the Virtual Dementia Tour, Priscilla thought it would be helpful.

For proprietary reasons, we're not allowed to show you inside the room where the tour is given, but we can explain how it works. Inserts with raised ridges and spikes go in your shoes. They simulate nerve damage in your feet when you're walking. They're really uncomfortable and even painful to have in your shoes.

Work gloves simulate how your hands become less sensitive as you age. They also can mimic nerve damage and arthritis in people's hands as they get older and they make it really difficult to pick up things and feel around where you are. The tour also utilizes classes. They simulate macular degeneration and a loss of eyesight as you get older. It's very difficult to see in your peripheral vision as well as straight ahead in some cases as you're looking through these classes.

Headphones are also worn throughout the entire tour. Playing in them, there is a constant background noise, including white noise and a random loud siren or alarm. There's this constant stimulation of your hearing and that's supposed to simulate the loss of hearing and just the background noises that can distract and unnerve somebody as they get older.

During the tour, Priscilla says she was disoriented, unnerved and in pain.

“I think the tour made me realize that all the noise and everything around them just confuses them,” she told us. “I think it's going to make me have more patience with her. I will always think back to that moment.”

Experts say caregivers need to think back to that moment, and remember for a loved one with dementia, that moment is their entire life.

“You knew someone was coming to get you soon,” Regional Director of Programming Jerry Lynn Daniels added. “For a person with dementia, there isn't a light at the end of the tunnel. No one's coming to get them and remove them from that room. That's what they feel all the time.”

article title: York Co. EMS gets grant for new technology
Text:
YORK Co., Va. (WVEC) -- New technology is on the way to York County Fire and Life Services.

It's called a power-loading fastening system.

It's expected to not only improve patient safety but also the safety of EMS providers doing constant lifting.

"The unit is connected to a piece of equipment that is inside the unit and it literally lifts the stretcher mechanically," Chief Steve Kopczynski said.

The money for the equipment was thanks to a competitive grant given to the county by the Virginia Department of Health's Office of Emergency Services Rescue Squad Assistance Fund.

The new devices are fully compatible with all the current equipment they're using now.

Once the stretcher is locked in, it's held in place, keeping the patient safe in any circumstance.

"If for any reason the medic unit would get into an accident, it's just a solid fastening system and it's the latest technology for EMS stretchers and stretcher fastening systems," Kopczynski said.

They are one of a very few Fire and EMS departments receiving the technology. They hope other departments across Hampton Roads will apply for similar grants to provide the safest transport for everyone as possible.

article title: Gloucester A&I exhibit now on display
Text:
The Gloucester Museum of History is now featuring a new exhibit on the history of the Gloucester Agricultural and Industrial School, also known as the Cappahosic Academy.

Gloucester A&I was an African American school that operated in Gloucester for 45 years and provided students with quality learning environment and encouraged students to pursue higher education.

Gloucester Museums Coordinator Robert Kelly said the exhibit was largely possible thanks to the efforts of Drs. Dorothy Cooke and Wesley Wilson, Bobby Ray and Deborah Billups who he said originally pitched the idea for the exhibit highlighting the African American school.

The exhibit features a wall of informative graphics by Mellen Street Creative, Hampton, and artifacts such as a diploma, ledgers and the school’s massive bell. The 309 pound, 24-inch diameter bell is an eye-catching piece for the exhibit and is on loan to the museum in honor of John DeHardit.

The bell was cast by McShane Foundry in Baltimore in 1891. Kelly said the records from the company show only one bell of its size made that year was the bell for Gloucester A&I. Kelly said the bell is a tangible artifact that anyone who’s been in school can relate to and understand. The bell had to be large and loud enough to reach classes and students across its 150-acre campus.

Another artifact is a book report from 1930, which is on a French book and is entirely written in French. One of the school ledgers on display shows the tracking of tuition for students enrolled, and how some were paying. It shows that some students worked at the school in the summer to pay their way through school.

Kelly said the documents and records provide a more personal connection to the school and those who attended. The goal of the school was for its students to graduate and pursue higher education. He said one example of this was Virginia L. Murray, who after graduating from the school then attended Howard University and New York University. She also taught in Albemarle, where today a school is named in her honor.

Gloucester A&I was founded by William Weaver in the 1880s with assistance from T.C. Walker, said Kelly. In 1891, the school’s financial struggles caused it to be purchased by the American Missionary Association which provided the institute consistent funding, allowing it to grow.

In 1899, the AMA replaced Weaver with Gloucester A&I’s then-assistant principal William Price. Kelly said Price along with his wife Carrie advanced the studies of the academy, introducing more courses in the humanities and science focused on farming. The changes made the school more well-rounded and attractive to students from all along the Chesapeake Bay.

Kelly said the records show students from Maryland and Washington, D.C., would take ferries to the port at Cappahosic. He said building the school only a mile from a steamboat-accessible pier allowed for the school’s reach to extend far past Gloucester. He said advertisements for the school at the time often mentioned how accessible the school was.

The notoriety of school attracted the attention of prominent civil rights activist Frederick Douglass, who delivered the school’s 1894 commencement speech.

The height of enrollment for the school was in 1925 with 159 students, said Kelly. Despite its success, the school was abruptly closed in 1933, an effect of the Great Depression. The AMA could no longer afford to support the school in the 1930s, and the once-prominent school was left to deteriorate.

Kelly said he hopes the new exhibit will attract people with their own stories of the school. He said the school’s existence is known throughout the county but isn’t well known. He said he would like the community to provide the museum with more stories and knowledge of the black school.

article title: 2 Artist in Residence events this weekend
Text:
Two guests of Arts on Main’s Artist in Residence program are holding public events this weekend in Gloucester.

Nora Murphy

Author and fiber artist Nora Murphy will give a performance, “COUNTERCLOCKWISE: An Irish Celebration to Welcome Spring,” at 6 p.m. Saturday at John’s Point Landing in Naxera. It is free and open to the public.

A fifth generation Irish-American, Murphy explores Native American genocide and pathways for healing in her book, “White Birch, Red Hawthorne,” and is currently writing a novel that explores ancient Irish ways to live in closer connection with the earth and one another. She will be in Gloucester through March 30.

Marcie Rendon

Author Marcie Rendon will read from one of her books at 1:30 p.m. Sunday in front of the Pocahontas mural at Gloucester Library, Main Street Center.

A citizen of the White Earth Nation, Rendon is a writer across many genres. She is included in Oprah Magazine’s 2020 list of 31 Native American authors to read, and she is the recipient of Minnesota’s 2020 McKnight Distinguished Artist Award.

Rendon’s Cash Blackbear series includes “Girl Gone Missing,” which was nominated for the 2020 Sue Grafton Memorial Award, and “Murder on the Red River,” which won the 2018 Pinckley Women’s Crime Novel Award. The third novel in the series, “Sinister Graves,” is scheduled for publication in October. Rendon also writes plays and children’s books.

The creative mind of Raving Native Theater, Rendon curated Twin Cities Public Television’s “Art Is … CreativeNativeReslience” in 2019. In 2017, she received the Loft’s Spoken Word Immersion Fellowship in conjunction with Diego Vazquez for their work with incarcerated women.

article title: Renowned sculptor to kick off Gloucester Arts Festival
Text:
Globally renowned sculptor Adrian Landon will exhibit at this year’s Gloucester Arts Festival, kicking off the monthlong festival with the installation of four of his sculptures on Main Street, including the kinetic piece, “The Mechanical Horse.” The festival will be held in June at various locations throughout the county.

Elizabeth Blackney, executive director of The Cook Foundation, which sponsors the festival, said that to have Landon exhibit locally “is humbling and thrilling.” He will have just completed his installation of his critically acclaimed “Wings of Glory” at Chatsworth House in Devonshire, England, for the Radical Horizons exhibit.

“Art transforms and transports us,” said Blackney. “Art informs and inspires communal experiences … Visionary artists ignite new generations of artists, engineers, thinkers, and community leaders.”

Landon was born and raised in New York City, “scribbling and eating Play-doh as a toddler,” said a press release. He attended the Academy of Arts in San Francisco in 2008, but after completing one year of industrial design, he left.

In 2009, as “a proud college dropout,” Landon’s journey as a sculptor began at the Art Students League of New York. He developed his initial body of work in the New York area, where in 2014 he completed his first Mechanical Horse and began to show his work nationally and internationally.

In 2019, Landon received the Honorarium Grant from Burning Man to make “Wings of Glory,” a giant mechanical Pegasus, his largest sculpture to date. He then went to the Buffalo Creek Art Center in Gardnerville, Nevada, to “build the impossible,” and currently lives in Reno, Nevada. He makes art at the Generator, a communal maker space.

The Cook Foundation has worked tirelessly for the past 23 years to expand access to the arts in Gloucester, said the release, adding, “through partnerships with the Virginia Symphony Orchestra, Plein Air artists, muralists, and sculptors like Seward Johnson, and now Adrian Landon, we are grateful to give back to this historic community and create opportunities to enjoy and benefit from all the arts.”

article title: Juneteenth celebration goes ahead with venue change
Text:
In spite of concerns prompted by a troubling post on social media days before the event, Sunday afternoon’s Juneteenth celebration in Gloucester went ahead, with a change in venue, as people gathered at The First United Baptist Church at White Marsh for this year’s “Celebration of Freedom, Family, Faith and Future.”

Juneteenth commemorates June 19, 1865, the day that enslaved people in Galveston, Texas, learned that they were, in fact, free. The following year, freed slaves had their first celebration of what is now known as Juneteenth, and it has been celebrated ever since. Juneteenth was recognized both a state and federal holiday in 2021.


PHOTO BY STEVE GREAVES During Sunday’s Juneteenth program, Gloucester County Sheriff’s Office Sgt. Jo Hughes surprised 8-year-old Gloucester resident Christian Montaque with a gift, a rare, solid plastic, “Junior Deputy” badge, to honor his good sportsmanship and thoughtfulness, after he’d defeated a couple of deputies in a cornhole game under shade trees and, on his own initiative, vanished into the church to return minutes later with bottles of water for all the officers. “He was truly thoughtful, as well as a great sportsman, very courteous to his competitors,” Hughes said.
As keynote speaker Dr. Cassandra Newby-Alexander pointed out, that date, while significant, is just one in a long and continuing process.

“Freedom is a process and we all need to come together to understand that freedom did not happen with one date and it is a journey that people are still on,” the Dean of the College of Liberal Arts at Norfolk State University said.

This year’s event was fun filled with inspiring speakers, live music, words of prayer, drawings for prizes and a multitude of vendors and exhibits for attendees to experience.

“We cannot do this all alone—we all need to come together,” Dr. Newby-Alexander told the crowd, as the nation continues the process of freedom and reconciliation. Part of the healing and coming together as a nation, she suggested, involves a true accounting of our past. “This is all our history and it cannot be hidden,” she said.
This year’s event was sponsored by the Woodville Rosenwald School Foundation, the Gloucester Union Relief Association, CircleUp Middle Peninsula and First United Baptist.

Throughout the event, attendees clapped and sang along with the music performed throughout the event. All in attendance came together and sang “Lift Every Voice and Sing” in unison and they all seemed to have enjoyed themselves. Some of the musicians who performed were the musical group George Robinson and Friends, soloist Charles McKeller, soloist D’Moria Garcia, musical group The Gresham Brothers, soloist Robert Brown and The Gloucester/Mathews Men’s Chorus.

There were words of prayer. Sister Maxine Trower delivered the invocation at the gathering and the Rev. Vincent Pryor also gave words of prayer as well.

There were drawings throughout the day where attendees were given prizes such as beautiful flowers and gift cards to local businesses in the county.

Attendees also engaged well with the informational exhibits and vendors at the event. Many signed up for notifications from the organizations that were there and took pamphlets that were provided. They also were given food, refreshments and little gifts to take with them. Attendees were also buying products from some of the vendors, including some Black-owned businesses in attendance.

Social media post

The location of the celebration was changed at the last minute because a possible threat of violence was posted on a local Facebook page.

Juneteenth committee member Sheila Crowley explained that when the comment was made on Facebook, the original venue, Flat Iron Crossroads, decided to cancel its entire weekend of Juneteenth festivities out of an abundance of caution. Events had also been planned for Friday and Saturday at Flat Iron Crossroads; some of those performances were incorporated into Sunday’s program.

However, the Juneteenth Celebration 2022 committee refused to be intimidated, said the Rev. E. Randolph Graham, who heads up the Juneteenth celebration committee, and instead changed the venue to The First United Baptist Church, where he serves as pastor and where the event had been held in years past. A Gloucester County Sheriff’s Office deputy and a Virginia State Trooper were both on site.

“The committee decided we could do it and do it safely at the church, so we moved forward, with police presence,” said Mr. Graham. “I’m 72, and I’ve been threatened before. I’m fully aware that many threats are just threats, and that sometimes they’re made by persons of influence and generate copycats. But with law enforcement’s presence, we were comfortable.”

Major Ryan Cookson of the GCSO said last week that the office, in consultation with the Gloucester Commonwealth Attorney’s Office and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, had determined that the comment made on social media was not a specific or credible threat, but was rather a distasteful comment.

The specific comment, which was made on a post about the upcoming celebration, stated, “…bet it ends abruptly due to a shooting or some other act of violence.”

Cookson said that the lieutenant in charge of the investigation into the comment conducted an interview with the subject, who said he was joking around and didn’t realize he would be taken seriously. A background check was done on the person, as well.

“We’re not trying to downplay this,” said Cookson. “Any time anybody makes such a comment it’s concerning, particularly in the current environment. But we have to pay attention to how we react, as well, because people do make stupid comments.”

Gloucester NAACP president Brenda Dixon wasn’t satisfied with that explanation. She said she believed that if a Black person had made a similar comment, “they’d be in jail.”

“When the sheriff said the man was just kidding around, it made me hotter,” said Dixon. “It was serious enough that the legal team at Flat Iron said it was a huge liability … The guy in Texas made a threat on social media and the guy in Buffalo made a threat on social media … It was totally disruptive, and it created fear in the elderly community.”
Text_Lower:
in spite of concerns prompted by a troubling post on social media days before the event  sunday afternoon’s juneteenth celebration in gloucester went ahead  with a change in venue  as people gathered at the first united baptist church at white marsh for this year’s “celebration of freedom  family  faith and future ”

juneteenth commemorates june 19  1865  the day that enslaved people in galveston  texas  learned that they were  in fact  free  the following year  freed slaves had their first celebration of what is now known as juneteenth  and it has been celebrated ever since  juneteenth was recognized both a state and federal holiday in 2021 


photo by steve greaves during sunday’s juneteenth program  gloucester county sheriff’s office sgt  jo hughes surprised 8-year-old gloucester resident christian montaque with a gift  a rare  solid plastic  “junior deputy” badge  to honor his good sportsmanship and thoughtfulness  after he’d defeated a couple of deputies in a cornhole game under shade trees and  on his own initiative  vanished into the church to return minutes later with bottles of water for all the officers  “he was truly thoughtful  as well as a great sportsman  very courteous to his competitors ” hughes said 
as keynote speaker dr  cassandra newby-alexander pointed out  that date  while significant  is just one in a long and continuing process 

“freedom is a process and we all need to come together to understand that freedom did not happen with one date and it is a journey that people are still on ” the dean of the college of liberal arts at norfolk state university said 

this year’s event was fun filled with inspiring speakers  live music  words of prayer  drawings for prizes and a multitude of vendors and exhibits for attendees to experience 

“we cannot do this all alone—we all need to come together ” dr  newby-alexander told the crowd  as the nation continues the process of freedom and reconciliation  part of the healing and coming together as a nation  she suggested  involves a true accounting of our past  “this is all our history and it cannot be hidden ” she said 
this year’s event was sponsored by the woodville rosenwald school foundation  the gloucester union relief association  circleup middle peninsula and first united baptist 

throughout the event  attendees clapped and sang along with the music performed throughout the event  all in attendance came together and sang “lift every voice and sing” in unison and they all seemed to have enjoyed themselves  some of the musicians who performed were the musical group george robinson and friends  soloist charles mckeller  soloist d’moria garcia  musical group the gresham brothers  soloist robert brown and the gloucester/mathews men’s chorus 

there were words of prayer  sister maxine trower delivered the invocation at the gathering and the rev  vincent pryor also gave words of prayer as well 

there were drawings throughout the day where attendees were given prizes such as beautiful flowers and gift cards to local businesses in the county 

attendees also engaged well with the informational exhibits and vendors at the event  many signed up for notifications from the organizations that were there and took pamphlets that were provided  they also were given food  refreshments and little gifts to take with them  attendees were also buying products from some of the vendors  including some black-owned businesses in attendance 

social media post

the location of the celebration was changed at the last minute because a possible threat of violence was posted on a local facebook page 

juneteenth committee member sheila crowley explained that when the comment was made on facebook  the original venue  flat iron crossroads  decided to cancel its entire weekend of juneteenth festivities out of an abundance of caution  events had also been planned for friday and saturday at flat iron crossroads; some of those performances were incorporated into sunday’s program 

however  the juneteenth celebration 2022 committee refused to be intimidated  said the rev  e  randolph graham  who heads up the juneteenth celebration committee  and instead changed the venue to the first united baptist church  where he serves as pastor and where the event had been held in years past  a gloucester county sheriff’s office deputy and a virginia state trooper were both on site 

“the committee decided we could do it and do it safely at the church  so we moved forward  with police presence ” said mr  graham  “i’m 72  and i’ve been threatened before  i’m fully aware that many threats are just threats  and that sometimes they’re made by persons of influence and generate copycats  but with law enforcement’s presence  we were comfortable ”

major ryan cookson of the gcso said last week that the office  in consultation with the gloucester commonwealth attorney’s office and the federal bureau of investigation  had determined that the comment made on social media was not a specific or credible threat  but was rather a distasteful comment 

the specific comment  which was made on a post about the upcoming celebration  stated  “…bet it ends abruptly due to a shooting or some other act of violence ”

cookson said that the lieutenant in charge of the investigation into the comment conducted an interview with the subject  who said he was joking around and didn’t realize he would be taken seriously  a background check was done on the person  as well 

“we’re not trying to downplay this ” said cookson  “any time anybody makes such a comment it’s concerning  particularly in the current environment  but we have to pay attention to how we react  as well  because people do make stupid comments ”

gloucester naacp president brenda dixon wasn’t satisfied with that explanation  she said she believed that if a black person had made a similar comment  “they’d be in jail ”

“when the sheriff said the man was just kidding around  it made me hotter ” said dixon  “it was serious enough that the legal team at flat iron said it was a huge liability … the guy in texas made a threat on social media and the guy in buffalo made a threat on social media … it was totally disruptive  and it created fear in the elderly community ”

article title: Concerts by the Bay announces season lineup
Text:
Concerts by the Bay will kick off its 2022-2023 season on Sunday, Sept. 25, with a performance by the Richmond Symphony.

October will showcase more Virginia talent with the Bobby BlackHat Band on Oct. 16. The following month brings “Hooray for Hollywood,” a well-known trio in the U.S. and Canada on Nov. 20. The first show of 2023 will feature Blue Ridge Musical Hall of Fame member Jeff Little on March 12. Grammy nominated pianist/singer/songwriter Judy Carmichael will cap off the season on April 23.

All performances are held on Sundays at 3 p.m. in the Harry M. Ward Auditorium at Mathews High School. Season tickets are available for all five concerts starting at $100, which also includes reciprocal concerts through Arts Alive in West Point and Rappahannock Concerts Association as well.

Single tickets can be purchased at the door or the Mathews County Visitor and Information Center for $25 each; students with student ID are admitted free.

To purchase subscriptions or get more information about the performances, go to www.concertsbythebay.org.

article title: Weekend Plans to perform at Flat Iron Halloween Party
Text:
Flat Iron Crossroads is gearing up for its second annual Halloween Party on Saturday, Oct. 29, with the funk/hip-hop band Weekend Plans kicking off the festivities at 6:30 p.m. Gates open at 5:30, with food from the Black Pearl food truck.

Weekend Plans, with its electrifying blend of funk, hip-hop, jazz, and soul, is back by popular demand after performing at Flat Iron’s Funk Fest in April, said a press release. Those attending will be among the first to hear a live rendition of their new single, “Dance With Me,” to be released on Friday, Oct. 28.

Hailing from Richmond, the eight-piece group released its debut album “State of Nine” in 2019 with Elephant Ear Studios. The band’s latest songs illustrate a sonic evolution that will be heard on the group’s second album. For more information, visit www.weekendplansmusic.com.

Flat Iron is urging everyone attending to dress for the spooky season, since prizes will be awarded for best costumes. Tickets are $20 and are available at www.flatironcrossroads.com.

Reminder: This Friday, Oct. 21, The Reverend Peyton’s Big Damn Band will perform at 7:30 p.m. Doors will open at 6 p.m. Tickets are $20 for adults. They are available at www.flatironcrossroads.com. Children 10 and under attend free of charge.

article title: Woman’s Club to host student art show Sunday
Text:
The Mathews County Woman’s Club will host an open house from 1-3 p.m. Sunday at the clubhouse on Route 14, exhibiting student artwork submitted to its annual show.

Local artist Gib Pulley has judged the art. Blue, red and yellow ribbons were given to the top three works in each category, with a best in show among blue ribbon winners awarded at each local school.

Hannah Davis of Lee-Jackson Elementary School won the award for her papier-maché pig; Thomas Hunter Middle School student Emily Lewis won the best in show for her pencil drawing; Avery Betz of Mathews High School won the award for giraffes.

These students will receive certificates for a class from the Bay School.

article title: Coach’s Comedy Club show to benefit West Mathews Community League
Text:
Coach’s Comedy Club, the third annual comedy show to benefit the West Mathews Community League Peninsula School at Bohannon, will be held at 7 p.m. on Saturday, April 14 at the Harry Ward Auditorium at Mathews High School.

The evening of stand-up comedy features Coach Tom Holaday of Mathews as master of ceremonies, along with comics Rob Reibold and David Beck.

Holaday, who retired from Mathews High School as a teacher and wrestling coach, started working in comedy clubs in 1992 “inspired by the joy and excitement he experienced getting laughs at high school banquets, assemblies, pep rallies and fundraisers,” according to a release. Holaday now tours clubs and speaks at corporate functions about his life as a father, teacher and coach.

“Everyone has a family, went to high school, and enjoys sports (or at least is married to someone who does). All can relate to the clean comedy of Coach Holaday’s life stories,” the release stated.

For more than 20 years, Reibold has been bringing his brand of comedy to stages all over the country. He has worked with famed comedians Lewis Black, Eddie Griffin and Patton Oswalt, as well as five cast members from “Saturday Night Live.” Among the venues where he has performed include Las Vegas’ “Comedy Stop at the Trop,” Funny Bone Comedy Clubs, and The Improvs from coast-to-coast.

Beck, a native Virginian, now resides in Springfield, Missouri. Originally starting out as an observational comedian, Beck has grown into a more versatile higher energy style which includes quick one liners. He has entertained audiences around the county, and recently around the world, with a tour entertaining the U.S. military in Japan and South Korea.

Not limited to just comedy clubs, Beck has a resume full of radio and television appearances. He has been heard on Fox Sports radio, and the nationally syndicated “Bob & Tom Show.” He has even ventured into the serious side of television with roles in Discovery Channel programming, such as The Prosecutors, New Detectives, and The FBI Files.

Money raised from the April 14 show will be used to replace windows in the historic Peninsula School building, which serves as a community center. Forty big original windows and six other smaller windows need replacing, according to West Mathews Community League president Al DeWitt.

“They’ve gotten past the point of no return,” he said of the windows. “They can’t be fixed.”

Tickets will be available at the door, as well as from WMCL members. This Saturday from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., the group will sell tickets in front of Best Value supermarket.

holaday  who retired from mathews high school as a teacher and wrestling coach  started working in comedy clubs in 1992 “inspired by the joy and excitement he experienced getting laughs at high school banquets  assemblies  pep rallies and fundraisers ” according to a release  holaday now tours clubs and speaks at corporate functions about his life as a father  teacher and coach 

“everyone has a family  went to high school  and enjoys sports (or at least is married to someone who does)  all can relate to the clean comedy of coach holaday’s life stories ” the release stated 

for more than 20 years  reibold has been bringing his brand of comedy to stages all over the country  he has worked with famed comedians lewis black  eddie griffin and patton oswalt  as well as five cast members from “saturday night live ” among the venues where he has performed include las vegas’ “comedy stop at the trop ” funny bone comedy clubs  and the improvs from coast-to-coast 

beck  a native virginian  now resides in springfield  missouri  originally starting out as an observational comedian  beck has grown into a more versatile higher energy style which includes quick one liners  he has entertained audiences around the county  and recently around the world  with a tour entertaining the u s  military in japan and south korea 

not limited to just comedy clubs  beck has a resume full of radio and television appearances  he has been heard on fox sports radio  and the nationally syndicated “bob & tom show ” he has even ventured into the serious side of television with roles in discovery channel programming  such as the prosecutors  new detectives  and the fbi files 

money raised from the april 14 show will be used to replace windows in the historic peninsula school building  which serves as a community center  forty big original windows and six other smaller windows need replacing  according to west mathews community league president al dewitt 

“they’ve gotten past the point of no return ” he said of the windows  “they can’t be fixed ”

tickets will be available at the door  as well as from wmcl members  this saturday from 10 a m  to 2 p m   the group will sell tickets in front of best value supermarket

article title: Fixed broadband equipment arriving; network buildout underway
Text:
Despite international and national supply chain issues, fixed wireless broadband equipment is arriving, and the network buildout is underway.

Open Broadband is working on the first phase of the local project in both Mathews and Gloucester counties, outfitting towers with antennas, receivers, and other new technology to help meet distance and speed goals for the internet service.

Much of the legwork of this project is being completed by the Gloucester and Mathews VATI (Virginia Telecommunication Initiative) committees, which work in concert to expand broadband in underserved areas, fulfilling all requirements of VATI grant funding. Both localities are working towards ubiquitous broadband access throughout their counties, according to a release from the Gloucester Department of Community Engagement and Public Information.

The VATI committee is made up of stakeholders, county leadership and IT professionals, both inside and outside the two counties, who have helped to guide the application and implementation processes. This grant was awarded in 2021 and will help build out a new fixed wireless network with North Carolina-based ISP Open Broadband. The grant will expand broadband access to 313 “serviceable units,” including 19 businesses, with 131 addresses located in Gloucester, two in Middlesex and 180 in Mathews.

For more information on the VATI grant, and broadband information in Gloucester County, residents can go to the Broadband Hub at https://gloucester-broadband-gcgis.hub.arcgis.com. Mathews County residents can go to the Broadband Advisory Board website at www.mathewscountyva.gov/255/Broadband-Advisory-Board.

Individuals interested in learning more about the services provided by Open Broadband can sign up for their regular updates at https://openbb.net/gloucesterco/#service-request.

article title: Breezeline launches program to promote digital literacy
Text:
Breezeline, the nation’s eighth-largest cable operator, has announced a series of online community education initiatives designed to foster digital literacy and equity while supporting online safety, a healthy tech-life balance, as well as promoting technology careers for young people.

Recognizing the great benefits that internet connectivity provides, but also being mindful that not all members of the community currently share in its benefits equally, as well as seeking to foster the responsible use of technology, Breezeline is supporting more than a half-dozen nonprofit organizations to promote these objectives in its communities.

These organizations include Digital Literacy for Seniors, Tech Life Balance, Cyber-Bullying Prevention, Online Safety, STEM for Girls and Promoting Tech Careers.

In its last fiscal year, Breezeline (formerly Atlantic Broadband) contributed more than $5 million in its support of community initiatives.

article title: Mathews takes a big step in broadband affordability
Text:
The good news about broadband in Mathews County just keeps coming.

Mathews Broadband Advisory Board chair Judy Rowe announced to county supervisors Tuesday night that the broadband affordability mandate she received when her advisory board was organized in 2019 is on the cusp of being met.

Rowe got word earlier this week that the Federal Communications Commission’s Affordable Connectivity Program will soon be available for eligible Mathews residents. The program provides a discount of up to $30 per month toward broadband service for eligible households, she said, and Breezeline and Open Broadband, two broadband providers in the county, are both participants in the program.

In addition, said Rowe, Breezeline is participating in the Virginia Telecommunications Initiative’s Line Extension Customer Assistance Program (LECAP), which assists eligible households with up to $3,000 of the cost of extending broadband lines down long driveways. Funding for the program comes from the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021.

“We’ve been going after affordability since we started,” said Rowe during a telephone interview. “I cannot believe these opportunities … The possibilities are just extraordinary.”

According to a handout Rowe shared, a federal qualifying household is one that meets at least one of the following criteria: has an income at or below 200 percent of the federal poverty guidelines; participates in such assistance programs as SNAP, Medicaid, Federal Public Housing Assistance, SSI, WIC, or Lifeline; meets the eligibility criteria for a participating broadband provider’s existing low-income program; or is approved to receive benefits under the free and reduced-priced school lunch or breakfast program, including through the USDA Community Eligibility Provision.

Rowe explained that the last two criteria are particularly important to Mathews. Since Mathews County has a poverty level that makes it eligible for free and reduced-price lunches and breakfasts for all of its students, she said that every Mathews household with a child attending public school will qualify for the broadband service discount of $30 per month.

In addition, Breezeline has recently created a low-income program for its customers, she said, and the price point for that service, coupled with the discount, will essentially make broadband free for any Mathews County Public School student who has Breezeline for a provider. Open Broadband is considering such a program, as well, she said.

A second benefit under the Affordable Connectivity Program that Rowe said will not involve her board is the provision of up to a $100 discount per eligible household on a one-time purchase of a computer, laptop or tablet, as long as the household contributes between $10 and $50 toward that purchase. The Affordable Connectivity Program is also available to people who participate in certain Tribal specific programs and those who received a Federal Pell Grant during the current award year.

Rowe said that those interested in the Affordable Connectivity Program should apply for the assistance online at www.affordableconnectivity.gov.
But households without internet shouldn’t be discouraged, she said. The Broadband Advisory Board is coordinating efforts to assist residents with their applications. People will be available to help out during this year’s Market Days, at public schools in Mathews on book day, and at Mathews Memorial Library on an ongoing basis. There will be other opportunities, as well, said Rowe, and those will be announced when the dates and locations are confirmed.

For residents who live down long lanes that exceed their internet service provider’s standard connection drop length, the online LECAP eligibility map shows that all households in Mathews with incomes of up to $89,066 are eligible for assistance of up to $3,000, while in some zip codes, households with incomes of up to $133,599 are eligible. According to a booklet put out by LECAP, the cost of extending lines down long driveways can run up to as much as $25,000, depending on the distance.

To see the zip code eligibility map, to find out more information, or to apply for assistance, visit https://dhcd.virginia.gov/lecap.

Rowe said she’s excited about all the opportunities that have become available to provide broadband to Mathews residents at an affordable price.

“We’ve been talking about these programs because we knew they were around, but it all came out last week,” she said. “It’s so exciting because it really is the affordable piece.”

Job opportunity in broadband

Open Broadband, a wireless internet provider, has partnered with Rappahannock Community College to offer a course this fall that teaches the concepts and practical skills for students to become internet installation technicians.

According to Nick Steward of Open Broadband, the course, Internet Installation Technician, will be offered on two successive weekends, beginning Sept. 10 and ending Sept. 18, at the college’s Glenns campus. The classes will be held from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. Saturday and Sunday, for a total of 32 hours of instruction.

“The course will introduce you to the technology involved in wireless internet via radio waves,” said Steward.

RCC’s Workforce Program Developer Kelly Clifton said the cost for the four-day class is $699, but all costs will be covered by a grant. All students have to do is fill out the registration form. No money is required.

Steward said that class size is limited, and the class is expected to fill up fast, so those interested should contact Clifton at kclifton@rappahannock.edu or 804-758-6794 as soon as possible.

article title: New RCC grant to support students in health science programs
Text:
Rappahannock Community College has received a grant from the Claude Moore Charitable Foundation. According to a news release, secondary schools in partnership with RCC will provide new opportunities for students pursuing health science careers as part of the Claude Moore Scholars Program.

The scholars program promotes partnerships between Virginia public school systems, post-secondary academic institutions and health care employers. It helps students transition between school and work in the medical field. It can begin as early as middle school and continue professional education in high school and beyond, the release said.

The education programs led by RCC are designed to meet the growing health care workforce needs of the region and the state.

In the first year of funding, the Claude Moore Charitable Foundation will support upgrades to lab classrooms at Northern Neck Technical Center, Bridging Communities Regional Career and Technical Center, and Gloucester High School to support Emergency Medical Technician, Pharmacy Technology and Practical Nursing instruction.

Participants will be dual enrolled with RCC and will be prepared to enter the workforce immediately upon high school graduation or to continue at RCC for further education in the health sciences, the release said.

Additional grant funds will be used to expand the capacity of all area schools to offer math and science dual enrollment classes by credentialing existing secondary school teachers.

For more information on RCC’s Claude Moore Charitable Foundation grant, contact Miles McCrimmon at mmccrimmon@rappahannock.edu or 804-333-6752.

article title: Library receives funding to promote digital literacy
Text:
Mathews Memorial Library has been selected as one of 160 public libraries nationwide to receive funding from the Public Library Association to conduct digital literacy workshops. The library was awarded $4,000 for program development and associated costs.

Increasingly, individuals find themselves challenged by technology when conducting routine tasks such as arranging appointments, applying for government services, seeking employment, and engaging in numerous other similar activities, said a press release.

The PLA Digital Literacy Workshop program, supported by AT&T, provides support to libraries to provide digital literacy training in their communities to help close the “digital divide,” said the release.

Beginning in October, the library plans to offer DigitaLearn workshops. Programs will be conducted at the library or at other selected sites, said the release. To date, the following workshops are scheduled: Computer Basics in October, Internet Basics in November, and Email Basics in February 2023. The exact dates and times will be announced later. Registration will be required.

Additional workshops during this time period and beyond may be scheduled, as well, said the release. Topics may include Cybersecurity, Videoconferencing, and Tablet Basics. “The mission of libraries has always been about equitable access to information, literacy, learning, and culture,” said PLA President Maria McCauley. Digital Literacy Workshops are intended to help community members build skills and confidence using technology.

For more information, call the library’s head of Technical Services, Greg Lewis, at 804-725-574.

article title: Broadband towers addressed by Mathews board
Text:
The Mathews County Board of Supervisors met Monday night in the historic courthouse to take up several items remaining on the agenda after the Sept. 21 meeting was recessed because of the late hour.

Picking up where the board left off, board chairman Paul Hudgins had Judy Rowe, chair of the Mathews Broadband Advisory Board, complete her report, which had been interrupted as she addressed issues the board raised with two broadband towers slated to be built in the county.

During the Sept. 21 part of the meeting, the board decided to table a decision on approving conditional use permits for building the two communication towers, which, once completed, would provide broadband coverage over much of the county. After a public hearing earlier in September, the planning commission recommended approval of the CUPs with the added condition that the towers have safety lighting.

However, supervisors questioned whether the parcel designated for one of the towers on property belonging to Mathews Volunteer Fire Department at Station 2 in Bohannon had wetlands that would need mitigation. Supervisor Dave Jones suggested that, if that were the case, the county might need to look for a different property for that tower.

“We don’t want to approve it to get put up in the wrong fashion,” said Hudgins. “We want to make sure we’re doing it right.”

Planning and Zoning Director James Knighton explained to the board that, while there could be non-tidal wetlands at the site, the CUP could still be approved pending the U.S. Army Corps’ wetlands assessment. He said that the poles being installed were monopoles that required no guide wires, thus minimizing their footprints. He said that up to a tenth of an acre of land can be impacted without having to pay mitigation fees.

The second broadband tower is proposed for the property where the Mathews Volunteer Rescue Squad is located in Hudgins.

Another issue was raised when the board asked County Administrator Ramona Wilson how much land was included in the lease agreements on the towers. She told the board that no specific amount of land had been designated for the structures in the lease agreements, and Jones said the lease agreements may need to be amended.

“We need to know if we’re leasing 10,000 square feet or 5,000 square feet,” he said. “Whatever promises were made, we want to make sure it’s done right.”

Supervisor Mike Walls brought up the additional issue of the cost of leasing the land from the Mathews Volunteer Fire Department and the Mathews Volunteer Rescue Squad at $1,200 a month.

“Does the county not own a piece of land where we could put at least one,” he asked. “If we have something to speed it up with another piece of property, we need to do it.”

Wilson explained that changing the property would require redoing all the geo-technical data, which would cost additional money and delay the project further.

During Monday’s portion of the meeting, Rowe explained to supervisors how the two tower sites were chosen. She outlined a lengthy process that involved many trips to various sites, starting with sites on county property, in order to find something that was suitable. She said broadband board consultants and representatives had talked to tower companies, broadband providers, and engineers in their quest, and they discovered that county properties were not suitable for the towers for various reasons, from being too close to already existing towers to not having enough room for ingress and egress. They considered various private properties, as well, but none of them were suitable either, said Rowe.

However, she said, it turned out that the sites where the Mathews Volunteer Rescue Squad building and Bohannon Station 2 were located were ideal because they were situated in areas that would enable them to reach the parts of the county that were underserved.

The county’s consultant, Broadband Telecom, did radio frequency analyses on the two sites as well as heat maps to determine where repeaters would need to be located, said Rowe, and they confirmed that the sites were ideal. She said the county had grant funding from the American Rescue Plan Act to pay for the towers, and the only thing left to do was have the board approve the CUPs. She said a mistake had been made in each of the engineering drawings, but they had since been corrected. Stakes that delineated the locations had somehow been moved at both sites, she said, adding that the surveyors were embarrassed by the mistakes.

“We believe we’re in compliance,” said Rowe. “We hope to have the results by the next board meeting, and we will have certifications to turn over to the Army Corps that we’re not in wetlands.”

Walls also made reference to comments made by a local resident during public comment period regarding danger to the public from radio waves and microwaves being transmitted from telecommunications poles.

Rowe said the technology being used on the poles is already being used everywhere in the country, and there are “all kinds of towers and poles all around the county,” she said, adding, “We take our chances every day” when talking on cell phones.

Supervisor Melissa Mason wondered how the stakes were moved on both properties, saying, “I hope nobody’s going on properties and moving stakes.”

“We’ve come a long way, and I would hate to see that someone is trying to hamper or derail the progress being made,” she said, “especially with statewide grant funding.”

Mason said that radio frequencies “are so entrenched in our everyday lives that we can’t miss it,” and that research on the matter had gone into the grant request. In addition, she said that a complaint had been made at the last meeting about the danger of radio frequencies, but the same person who initiated the complaint “was willing to make land available for the towers.”

“This is something that everybody will benefit from,” she said, “and we need to keep our eyes going forward.”

During public comment period, George Machen of Foster stated that the complaint was not made by the same people who had offered land for the towers. He said he and his family made the complaint, but it was his brother who owned the property in question. He said the board should look for land it wouldn’t have to pay for to erect the tower, since “$1,200 a month—$300,000 for 10 years—is quite an investment.” He also called for proof the towers were safe before going forward.

Donnie Lewis, president of Mathews Volunteer Fire Department, rebutted Machen’s comments, saying the equipment will be located 200 feet up, and that there are no homes within 1,500 feet of the tower. Money from that tower will be used to buy fire trucks, hose, and other equipment, he told the board.

“If we don’t get it, we’ll just be asking you for it,” Lewis said. “Don’t base your decision on studies that don’t apply.”

“The fire department is one hundred percent on board with this cell tower,” he said.

Rowe stated additionally that the revenue generated by the towers “will be substantially more than $1,200 a month.”

In other matters, the board:

—Unanimously approved providing tax relief for the disabled after a public hearing on changing the regulation governing tax relief for the elderly to add relief for the disabled, as well;

—Unanimously approved a request by Building Official Kevin Zoll to demolish the maintenance shop located in the old Davidson home, a former gas station located adjacent to Port Fun, and replace it with a 50’ by 80’ maintenance shop located farther back on the 3½-acre property. The board also approved removing 41 trees on the property to accommodate the project and allocating $350,000 to pay for it;

—Directed County Attorney Andrea Erard to draft a curtailed version of the proposed noise ordinance and have another meeting with Sheriff Mark Barrick on the matter, then bring the issue before the board at its next meeting;

—Heard from Knighton that he had received the draft permit for the Hole in the Wall dredging project from the Army Corps of Engineers and is waiting on one document from the Virginia Department of Environmental Quality in order to be able to send out a request for proposals to complete the dredging, and

—Directed Wilson to talk to VDOT Saluda Residency Administrator Lee McKnight about doing a traffic study at the end of Old Ferry Road adjacent to the Cherry Point neighborhood to determine whether it would be feasible to reduce the speed limit to 25 mph, as requested by residents in the neighborhood.

the county’s consultant  broadband telecom  did radio frequency analyses on the two sites as well as heat maps to determine where repeaters would need to be located  said rowe  and they confirmed that the sites were ideal  she said the county had grant funding from the american rescue plan act to pay for the towers  and the only thing left to do was have the board approve the cups  she said a mistake had been made in each of the engineering drawings  but they had since been corrected  stakes that delineated the locations had somehow been moved at both sites  she said  adding that the surveyors were embarrassed by the mistakes 

“we believe we’re in compliance ” said rowe  “we hope to have the results by the next board meeting  and we will have certifications to turn over to the army corps that we’re not in wetlands ”

walls also made reference to comments made by a local resident during public comment period regarding danger to the public from radio waves and microwaves being transmitted from telecommunications poles 

rowe said the technology being used on the poles is already being used everywhere in the country  and there are “all kinds of towers and poles all around the county ” she said  adding  “we take our chances every day” when talking on cell phones 

supervisor melissa mason wondered how the stakes were moved on both properties  saying  “i hope nobody’s going on properties and moving stakes ”

“we’ve come a long way  and i would hate to see that someone is trying to hamper or derail the progress being made ” she said  “especially with statewide grant funding ”

mason said that radio frequencies “are so entrenched in our everyday lives that we can’t miss it ” and that research on the matter had gone into the grant request  in addition  she said that a complaint had been made at the last meeting about the danger of radio frequencies  but the same person who initiated the complaint “was willing to make land available for the towers ”

“this is something that everybody will benefit from ” she said  “and we need to keep our eyes going forward ”

during public comment period  george machen of foster stated that the complaint was not made by the same people who had offered land for the towers  he said he and his family made the complaint  but it was his brother who owned the property in question  he said the board should look for land it wouldn’t have to pay for to erect the tower  since “$1 200 a month—$300 000 for 10 years—is quite an investment ” he also called for proof the towers were safe before going forward 

donnie lewis  president of mathews volunteer fire department  rebutted machen’s comments  saying the equipment will be located 200 feet up  and that there are no homes within 1 500 feet of the tower  money from that tower will be used to buy fire trucks  hose  and other equipment  he told the board 

“if we don’t get it  we’ll just be asking you for it ” lewis said  “don’t base your decision on studies that don’t apply ”

“the fire department is one hundred percent on board with this cell tower ” he said 

rowe stated additionally that the revenue generated by the towers “will be substantially more than $1 200 a month ”

in other matters  the board

—unanimously approved providing tax relief for the disabled after a public hearing on changing the regulation governing tax relief for the elderly to add relief for the disabled  as well;

—unanimously approved a request by building official kevin zoll to demolish the maintenance shop located in the old davidson home  a former gas station located adjacent to port fun  and replace it with a 50’ by 80’ maintenance shop located farther back on the 3½-acre property  the board also approved removing 41 trees on the property to accommodate the project and allocating $350 000 to pay for it;

—directed county attorney andrea erard to draft a curtailed version of the proposed noise ordinance and have another meeting with sheriff mark barrick on the matter  then bring the issue before the board at its next meeting;

—heard from knighton that he had received the draft permit for the hole in the wall dredging project from the army corps of engineers and is waiting on one document from the virginia department of environmental quality in order to be able to send out a request for proposals to complete the dredging  and

—directed wilson to talk to vdot saluda residency administrator lee mcknight about doing a traffic study at the end of old ferry road adjacent to the cherry point neighborhood to determine whether it would be feasible to reduce the speed limit to 25 mph  as requested by residents in the neighborhood

article title: ‘Still a long way to go’: Gloucester event celebrates Juneteenth
Text:
Sweltering heat marked Saturday’s Juneteenth celebration in Gloucester, but it deterred neither the enthusiastic group of speakers who came to deliver a message nor the audience members who gathered at First Baptist Church to hear what those speakers had to say.


PHOTO COURTESY CIRCLEUP MIDDLE PENINSULA
Gloucester historian Dr. Wesley Wilson was the keynote speaker for the 2021 Juneteenth celebration, held on Saturday at First Baptist Church.
The Rev. E.R. Graham presided over the event, which was sponsored by the Gloucester Union Relief Association, the Woodville Rosenwald School Foundation, and CircleUp Middle Peninsula. Graham emphasized that it was the first time Juneteenth was being celebrated as a national holiday.

“It’s an indication that we should continue to press on, press on, press on,” he said.

With devotions by the Rev. Vincent Pryor, the day included inspirational music by the Gloucester/Mathews Male Chorus, refreshments by the youth of First Baptist, and a COVID-19 vaccination clinic operated by Three Rivers Health District. There were special presentations by Corrine F. Young, who read her “Juneteenth Poem”; D’Mori Garcia, who read his poem “Look at Me, Please” and C.J. McKeller, who played the saxophone.

Representatives of the sponsoring organizations took turns speaking, with the Rev. Bradley A. Holmes of the Gloucester Union Relief Association giving thanks for the role Graham played in keeping the 13 churches of the association connected during the pandemic.

Chuck Crook of CircleUp Middle Peninsula reflected on the past, suggesting that the Texas slaves who were the last to be freed after the Civil War wouldn’t have been welcomed to try on clothes at the general store or to sit down for a meal at the local restaurant. He recalled the days of segregation and said many of the same issues continue to this day.
“June 19, 1865 was a great day,” he said, “but there’s still a long way to go to build the type of community we all want and deserve.”

Bobby Ray of the Woodville Rosenwald School Foundation spoke about the diligent efforts of the Black community to raise the money to provide an education for their children, and about T.C. Walker approaching Sears Roebuck founder Julius Rosenwald, resulting in the construction of six schools in Gloucester for African American children.

Gloucester teacher Brian Teucke, pronouncing himself “a proud anti-racist,” spoke resoundingly of righting the wrongs of the past through a joint effort of African Americans and labor, and he urged everyone to “normalize celebrating Black lives,” “normalize celebrating Black educators” and “normalize celebrating Black children.”

“When we normalize celebrating Black children,” he said, “we offer affirmation that they hold in their hands the power to change the world.”

Keynote address

The keynote address was provided by local historian Dr. Wesley C. Wilson, who spoke about what it must have been like for the 250,000 enslaved people in Texas who were freed on June 19, 1865.

Wilson dismissed the idea that the slaves had previously been unaware of the Emancipation Proclamation and its implications for their own lives. He said Lincoln had first signaled his intent to sign the proclamation in 1862, when he introduced it to his cabinet, and it was publicized widely long before it actually went into effect in 1865.

The proclamation was offered as a “carrot-and-stick” proposition, he said, with Lincoln declaring only the slaves in the rebelling states free, hoping that those states would return to the Union if they thought it would mean keeping their slaves. It also offered the slaves in the rebelling states a place to “run and hide” with Union forces if they wanted to escape. It was unlikely that those messages didn’t reach Texas slaveholders, said Wilson, or that the enslaved people they would affect didn’t overhear their White enslavers talking about them.

The reason the Black people in Texas didn’t escape, theorized Wilson, was that they were far from Union encampments, so they had no place to run to if they did manage to get away. He pointed out that hordes of slaves went to “Freedom Fort” in Hampton during the war, but that there was a problem with the “unique and sheer power held by the White men of Texas.”

“In no state did slavers give up their slaves willingly,” said Wilson. “It took Union troops to separate the slaves from their enslavers.”

It’s more important now than ever to celebrate Juneteenth, said Wilson, because “it provides a reminder of the hardship and heartache they suffered.”

“Because they knew,” he said. “We can only imagine how much strength and perseverance it took to keep on when you knew you were free but had no place to run and hide. They not only kept the faith, but they stood tall.”

Wilson told the story of the Greek god Sisyphus, who was forced by Zeus to roll a boulder up a hill for eternity. Every time he would get near the top, the stone would roll back down. Wilson said that Sisyphus could have solved his problem by taking a piece of the mountain back down with him each time, eventually levelling the mountain and ending his ordeal.

“Let us see ourselves not as mountain climbers but as mountain levelers,” said Wilson. “We may not be able to right these voter suppression laws and other laws right now, but we can dream the impossible dream and make it come true.”

Other speakers who offered reflections were the Rev. Julia Forrest, who talked about the history of Antioch Baptist Church; Toni Oliva, who shared the history of Bethel Church; Brenda Dixon of the Gloucester NAACP, who spoke of ongoing efforts to end inequality in economics, education, health care and other areas; and Sheila Crowley, who reflected on people coming together last summer, both locally and across the nation, in the wake of the murder of George Floyd and the renewed push for social justice.

Bessida Cauthorne White of the Middle Peninsula African-American Genealogical and Historical Society talked about various celebrations that marked turning points in the efforts to free those who were enslaved, and Edith Turner of the Mathews Historical Museum called for people to work together to bring about freedom and justice for all.
